[[Abel Prize]] {{small|(2009)}}}} }} '''Mikhail Leonidovich Gromov''' (also spelled '''Mikhael Gromov''' or '''Michael Gromov'''; {{lang-ru|link=no|Михаи́л Леони́дович Гро́мов}}; born 23 December 1943), is a French–Russian mathematician known for important contributions in many different areas of mathematics. He is considered a geometer in a very broad sense of the word. In 2009 he was awarded the [[Abel Prize]] "for his revolutionary contributions to geometry". ==Biography== Mikhail Gromov was born on 23 December 1943 in [[Boksitogorsk]], [[Soviet Union]]. His father was Leonid Gromov and his mother was Lea Rabinovitz.{{cite book|title=The International Who's Who, 1997–98|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4XNtwLEbl7wC|year=1997|publisher=Europa Publications|isbn=978-1-85743-022-6|pages=591}}{{MacTutor Biography|id=Gromov}} Both his parents were pathologists.Gromov, Mikhail. "A Few Recollections", in {{cite book|author1=Helge Holden|author2=Ragni Piene|title=The Abel Prize 2008–2012|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=tEprnQEACAAJ|date=3 February 2014|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg|isbn=978-3-642-39448-5|pages=129–137}} (also available on Gromov's homepage: [http://www.ihes.fr/~gromov/PDF/autobiography-dec20-2010.pdf link]) Gromov was born during [[World War II]], and his mother, who worked as a medical doctor in the Soviet Army, had to distance herself from the front line in order to give birth to him.[http://www.ems-ph.org/journals/newsletter/pdf/2009-09-73.pdf Newsletter of the European Mathematical Society, No. 73, September 2009, p. 19] When Gromov was nine years old,[http://www.lemonde.fr/planete/article/2009/03/26/mikhail-gromov-le-genie-qui-venait-du-froid_1172835_3244.html Le Monde – Mikhaïl Gromov, le génie qui venait du froid] (in French) his mother gave him the book ''Numbers and Figures'', by [[Hans Rademacher]] and [[Otto Toeplitz]], a book that piqued his curiosity and had a great influence on him.Note: This book was translated to English as ''The Enjoyment of Mathematics'', the original title in German is ''Von Zahlen und Figuren''. Gromov studied for a doctorate (1973) in [[Saint Petersburg|Leningrad]], where he was a student of [[Vladimir Rokhlin (Soviet mathematician)|Vladimir Rokhlin]].http://cims.nyu.edu/newsletters/Spring2009.pdf He is now a permanent member of [[IHÉS]], and a Professor of Mathematics at [[New York University]]. ==Work== Gromov's style of geometry features a "coarse" or "soft" viewpoint, often analyzing asymptotic or large-scale properties. His impact has been felt most heavily in [[geometric group theory]], where he characterized groups of polynomial growth and created, along with [[Eliyahu Rips]], the notion of [[hyperbolic group]]; [[symplectic topology]], where he introduced [[pseudoholomorphic curves]], and in [[Riemannian geometry]]. His work, however, has delved deeply into [[Mathematical analysis|analysis]] and [[algebra]], where he will often formulate a problem in "geometric" terms. For example, his [[homotopy principle]] (h-principle) on [[differential relation]]s is the basis for a geometric theory of [[partial differential equations]].
